transcript.content: See? Strokes - Someday. Now that was a better--a better choice, wunnit, to start off with? Um, oh hello, uh.. ladies and gentlemen.. Xfm 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais, obviously. Steve.. Mitchell.
Now, come on, let's get my name right from now. Tha-that novelty has worn off.
The Guardian got it wrong. It's Steve Merchant.
The more I say Mitchell the more people will think it might--
Um, but Karl wanted to start off with the Stereophonics.
'Cos it was "a newer track." And Karl now, we've made him what he is. He was nothing when we found him
Nobody. He was like work experience
And now he's going, "Oh, we should start off with the Stereophonics" and I'm going, "Karl"--
Trying to tell you what to do, Rick.
--"if I want anyones opinion... I don't."
Well, you'd probably come to me I'd imagine.
So, just keep it... just 'cuz he was in, what was it, Pilkie's Makin Music?
I'll bet you never pleased a crowd once.
Go on then. What'd you play? What's the biggest gig you ever played?
I did, uh... like a social club.. gig.
And it wasn't just about the music, either.
What else could it be about?
I used to take prizes... and cigars, and stuff.
I just love these like fourteen-year-old Mancs hangin' out, goin', "Let's go down there, he might have some fags and cigars for us."
Well, it was whatever, like... was on me mom and dad's dressing table.
That could have been deeply embarrassing.

I'm not saying... that... at any point in your upbringing, your parents left around any kind of... marital aid on the dressing table. Don't think I'm saying that, Karl. I'm not suggesting--Look he doesn't like this, does he?
It's about his parents having sex.
I think I was an accident.
I think--I think it's been ongoing.
Just because me brother and sister are quite older than me.
Yeah, me too. I was an accident, I know that, yeah. How olds your, uh, brother and sister?
Uhhmmm.. I think me sister's about... thirty-nine.
Right, so, yeah. My next one's eleven years older than me.
Do you want to have a hug, you two? Or...
You dealing with it now? You got over it?
Well, would you like to see us have a hug? Ooh.
Oh. You had a mobile disco as well, didn't you?
You're havin' a laugh aren't you. I was--every single gig I did... dynamite. People loved it. It was stormin'.
I ran it from about the age of fourteen to... eighteen?
What was it called? Was it called anythi--
The name of our mobile disco?
It had two names in its lifetime.
It started its life as... bear with it--
Oh my god... "The Rock and Roll DJ"... that's the worst...
Yeah. That's the most appalling. But then, it became pretty bad after that... when it became... "The Fantasy Island Roadshow"
'Cuz everyone up to you looked like Tattoo?
Partly that. And I--'cuz I liked the program Fantasy Island.
Why did you like the program Fantasy Island?
Well, it was about love, on an island.
It wasn't. It was about a midget on an island.
No. The midget was a minor character. It was about people going on an island to find love and romance.
You obviously switched off once the midget had gone off and said, "There's the plane."
That's that then. Your parents went, "That's over then."; "It's only five minutes long?"; "Yeah, well it's..."
What happened then? Cuz didn't they aah--they, um, acted out their fantasies on an island, eh?
Well people would pay to go to the island, um...
To live out their own romantic fantasies and invariably that was (unintelligable).
It was always roman--it was always about... getting off with people?
Yeah, it was a kind of love island. Yeah.
Well, no not always. Sometimes they might be uh...
Maybe I didn't watch a whole one. Maybe I did just see him like... smackin' little Tattoo around the head.
I think you did, mhmph. I think you just saw the trailer.
So what did they sort of go? "I've always wanted to have... someone in..."

Well, no. It might be something like, you know, "I've always wanted to, uh, to sort of, to live out, uh, being a gunslinger in a wild west frontier town," you know, so you might kind of... create that fantasy.
So what's that got to do with love--?
Well, invariably he'd find love, or he'd sort out some emotional problem he had. It was much more a spiritual and emotional journey than it was about little midgets runnin' around.
So basic--but was it, like, um, "Oh. I'd like to be a cowboy and I'd like to have been one with a shag."
Yeah, it was like Jim'll Fix It. Like those letters you wrote to Jim'll Fix It.
"I'd like to meet Five Star and if something happens, so be it."
No, I have to just say once though--
This is about my, this is my DJing credentials. I was once playing, uh... music at a scout jamboree.
When I was about seventeen, sixteen, seventeen.
Big gig. There was a thousand scouts there.
Right, and I'll tell you this, we were playin' our stuff. They were lovin' it. They were dancing, it was in a big marquee, right?
I slapped on Smells Like Teen Spirit.

They went mad for it. They were moshing, they were climbing up the poles. The organizers were going, "Switch that off! Switch that off!" Right? They're going crazy, and I was there going, "No! That's what they like. I'm going to do it." And--
It was unbelievable, it was just like Foot Loose. Then I came in with Rage Against the Machine - Killing in the Name Of; the place went wild.
And they were trying to get me off the decks. It was like Bill... it was like Bill Grundy interviewing the Sex Pistols.
And then when... when the head andevribud had you killed...
Right, by some mafia thing, it was all hushed up. Then the scouts went there one night with all candles and sat by your grave and the... and that was the end of the film. It was a film, I assume?
I assume this didn't really happen.
Yes it did, I swear to God I was playing Smells Like Teen Spirit and it went wild and the organizers were going, "Switch that off! They're going crazy," and I was going, "No! It's what they want."
That, to me.. I've known you about four years and I've heard all these things--
That must be the highlight of your life.
It's--you've never had anything that good--
One day I hope to sleep with a lady...
...and hopefully that'll--it will slide into second place.
I love the fact that you had at least three minutes to get that right
To prepare and get that right.
I know, but my mouth was full of Maryland Cookies.
This'll, ah, this'll blow your mind. He came in, do you know what he bought, for himself, at about 10? Penguins.
Oh, I've never liked Wagon Wheels
Have you not been a fan?
No, no. But sorry 'bout that, it's The Clash and Rock the Cashbah.

Um, talking about records, have I told you that time my brother-in-law, um... uh, he was moving out of his place and I think moving in with my sister and I was about like, um, I dunno, thirteen. Um... and so he was about, I dunno, thirty. And movin' in--And he brought round all um.. uh, his records when he was storage to leave them at our house, right? And he all these old sort of records, fifties and sixties records, they're Elvis, right? And, uh um, and uh, they, uh... put them upstairs... and I was looking through them, and uh... it was just all like Elvis stuff and Beatles stuff and there was a mate of mine who loved Elvis, okay?

...loads of chemicals. Yeah. He had loads of chemicals and I was into chemistry, and uh, he said, "I'll swap you some chemicals for them." So I sort of nicked about five Elvis singles and I got all these chemicals and then... just guilt--

Just things like, you know, um... uh... just things like from a chemistry set... you know, crystals and metals and magnesium, all that sort of stuff that I just like to muck around with. And um... and uh... and then the guilt just... hit me, and just I thought, "Well, he's gonna notice that." And I just... one night, I just came down stairs and I confessed to my mum. She went, "Alright... well... I won't tell him, but you've got to be good." And it sort of like, I was just... really, really good for a year.
And then, and then I was... have I told you this, am I not--?
No, no. You've just reminded me of something.
And then... I remember, um, when I was about eighteen... uh... my brother was talking about it... and he said, "Did you ever, um, uh... play those records I left for you?"
He told my mum, "These are for Ricky." She just didn't tell me.
And uh, that was it. That's why I was good.
But you've never stolen anything since, have you?
No... I don't, I don't, I don't...
Except that spate of uh... of shop-lifting after that to teach your mum a lesson.
Yeah, yeah. Well, we went round uh, and uh.. arson.
Uh, no, no. I did, I just couldn't believe it. I just... oh.
I remember um... and I think all kids go through a phase of shop-lifting.
And, and... wh-wh-when I was going through it...
Um, I used to just--just little things. Just like, magic markers and uh... magazines, Mars bars, that sort of thing.
And um... And one day, right?

Uh... me mate... Antony, his mom called up my mom and said, "I've got to uh... I've got to meet up with ya. I've got to have a word with ya." And uh... she said, "What about?"; she said, "I don't want to talk about it over the phone." So she goes, "Oh, right. Well, yeah... come round tonight, then." So anyway, me mum sees me, she--she doesn't want to be in an awkward position and like... be a bit embarrassed and what have you so she sees me and she goes, "Right. Antony's mum is coming 'round. What 'ave you been doing?"
So I go, "Oh god..."; I said, "I've been nicking stuff."
So she goes, "Like what?" and I go, "Not big stuff... I've had a few... calculators and, uh, Mars bars and stuff."
"How many?"; "I'll just work it out, hold on"
Ricky pretends to press calculator buttons
How many calculators do you need?
So it was when that phase...
Everyone wanted a calculator; it was like the trendy thing, wunnit?
Yeah. In Manchester a couple years ago, yeah.
So um... so anyway. So, I told her all this and I confessed to like--
Computers will make it there one day.
Confessed to nicking all this stuff... she comes 'round. She only wanted to borrow some money.
She said, "Oh... I don't like asking... I was a bit embarrassed to ask you over the phone but can I borrow 20 quid?"
And it's the same sort of thing to yours...
And he went, "Hold on mum, let me just work out the interest on that."
"About ten percent... she'll owe you Â£4.40."
S-so... your mum was a loan shark.
--you'd been nicking stuff with your, with that other... 'cause what I'm saying is presumably you got your mate in trouble
No, no no no no, no.
She went, "No worries, I'll just go and get my purse, it's on the dressing table."
What other things did you used to give away at your disco, then, that you would find on the dressing table. You used to go into, um, your parents room and go, "What can I give away tonight?"
It was--it was stuff like I sai--Cigars.
Uh... I had a pair of tights.
Unopened... you know how you get 'em in like a long--
Who did you give that to?
Just whoever.. did the prize. It was stuff like, you know... di--we did like a little raffle.
I could just imagine Karl going, "This is for a pair of... pretty polly, shear!"
Brilliant. Who's going joy riding this week? Now who's doing a bank job this week?
Exactly. That's what it is used for, yeah.
Just.. little bits, you know... unopened makeup... just stuff like that.
And did your parents not notice?
Nah... 'cause it's stuff that... you're not that bothered about. If a telly went missing, they'd notice it.
They would, wouldn't they? They'd be staring at a wall for three days.
But a pair of tights and cigar and that...

But it's funny as well, like, 'cause like how you had--you had two names... I just, like, remembered. I started off as um... "Dazzling Darren's Disco." Just because the first lights I could afford belonged to someone who had their name put in lights.
So I went along with that name for a bit.
You had to pretend you were called Darren.
And then it went on to... "Pilkie's Makin Music"
I know, shall we have some more music?
We've got the... Cooper Temple Clause lined up.
The Cooper Temple Clause - Who Needs Enemies?
Yeah. Okay.. d-d-don't keep saying it.
We've been digging around in Karl's office, haven't we?
He's a little bit nervous about this.
But he doesn't need to be.
I don't think he is because--
You just need to trust us, Karl. Just trust us. Trust us with the music. Trust us with the pe-speach output. Trust us with the--
That's easy for me to say.
Well it's just, I-I-I'm conscious, Rick, that sometimes we're a little ill-prepared--
--on this show. And I just wanted to make sure we were sort of... keeping ourselves abreast of developments, changes at the station, policy--
Thanks. Uh... you know, policies particularily, and um... I was lucky enough to stumble across this, and I feel that actually a couple weeks ago we were a little ill-prepared--
This is the Xfm, uh, information. It's the guidelines if you will--
--on how to react to deaths, disasters, and other news emergencies.
Yeah. And there's very important ones--
--like a-a-a royal death is like you know...

Well, there's certain criteria. I mean obviously... The general guidelines state that, "Occassionally something will happen in the world that prompts Xfm to break away from the normal programming and react to our audience's feelings of shock or grief."--
Uh, "As broadcasters, we have a duty to think carefully"--
They're not talking about our show, are they?
I don't mean, no, no, like people being caused grief 'cause Karl's on the air.
A royal dying, or some kind of um, you know, major disaster.
Um... "We should be able to tailor our output to show that we feel the same way as the audience"--
Uh, "That would never involve the station shutting down completely," Rick.
I want to reassure you of that now.
And, "It would never involve playing classical music or stopping all speech content."
Sure. 'Cause a lot of, th-they put that in there 'cause a lot of stations, that's exactly what they do.
Xfm... have deemed it... th-th-th-that we don't have to go completely down the line there. We have to do our own unique way.
"People need company at times like this."
"And... should be able to look to us for both factual information and emotional reaction."
Uh... "We simply have to change our tone and our playlist to show that we're all feeling the same thing."
"Be it, Oh my god, I can't believe this is happening... or, Well, it's pretty sad but she was 101 after all."
And that's actually in that book, isn't it?
That's what it actually says in the general guidelines.
That's as they are stated... Um, "If you should hear about the death of a major royal"--
You're actually reading this, by the way...

Yeah, I'm actually reading this now. "What you should do is say nothing about this on air under any circumstances, drop all the ads and promos from your schedule, and if Chris Smith, the news guy, is in the building get him in the studio immediately."
If Smitty is uh, I don't care where he is; I don't care if he's on holiday.
Let's phone him up now and tell him someone has died.
To see how he would react? To get him down here?
See how long it takes him to get down here. Where does--where does Smitty live?
'cause, I know where he lives, he lives a cave and he slides down a pole.
And he gets into a car. His butler a--i--is up there and he--he sort things out.
I suppose the approach there is that only Chris can deliver this tragic news.
If it was you or I, we couldn't--
Yeah. It wouldn't, it wouldn't, it wouldn't... have the same. Uh, I remember, do you remember the Xfm, uh, as it first started, it launched the day after um, uh Princess Diana died.
And I'd never done radio before; I was nervous enough--
And it was lorrge and it was, uawh, howsf
Because, I--I--was it--was it the first night, because what I'd forgotten actually until you mentioned that then is that of course you used to host your own phone-in show.
I had forgotten all about that.
And I gave that up after a week because it was just too stressful.
I have never seen a man so petrified.
He spent all his time preventing people getting through on the phone lines.
He just wouldn't let people come on air.

And, and, and, for the fir--when I have to go on air, right? Um, my mates sorta like came over the first day and they were mucking around and uh, I was having a drink with them, where I used to work and I was going, "I've got to go on air in a minute," and I was like... drinking Shandy or summat 'cause I was saying, "I don't want to be drunk," and everything. And, uh, I kept saying, "Don't swear."
Telling my mates not to swear and they look at me like I was mental. I was going, "Don't swear 'cause I'll swear." I was terrified of two things: um... just, swearing--
And--and, and operating the desk. I thought, "I'm gonna... Even if I get through operating the desk, I'm gonna swear." And it just, oh, it was--it was just awful.
Didn't you, um, didn't you spill coffee over the machine and then go, "Oh, shit," on your first link?
I can't remember. But I know it wasn't a triumph.
No, I started off, it was all about the music, and I started off with a classical piece--
--by a bloke called Kunz who's a, uh, German composer.
So I knew I was--it was okay.
You were off. You were off.
So how did it go then, 'cause I remember it was appalling.
Look! Karl! He's a composer. Look it up.
Right. 0-8700-800-1234 if you know what they composer I'm talking about.
You know what people are like...
They take things... badly, don't they?
--uh, a bull to a red rag, or whatever.
Ricky tries to suppress his laugh

Yeah, but the thing is we say bad words and get in trouble, but I was listening to Heart um, uh... the other day and they played Luther Vandross and i--the-whe-that-that song. Uh... neageadea... what is it? Never too much, never too much... Play a little bit; the lyric in this is just disgusting.
Woke up today, looked at your picture just to get me started...
Woke up today, looked at your picture just to get me started.
That is filthy, play it again.
Woke up today, looked at your picture just to get me started...
That's just filthy. What a filth... I mean--

Just taying 'bout that. Imagine that. He's got a young girl's picture and he's going, "Oh, thanks for that." And then he phones her up and what's it say? You know that picture you gave me. She goes, "Yeah." He goes, "Well... I looked at it just to get me started." That poor young woman must be...
I imagine more that, like... she's sleeping... and he just sneaks in and just, he's got a Polaroid camera, she wakes up and she goes, "What you doin'?"
She goes, "What you up to?" He goes, "No, I'm just taking a picture."; "Well, why?"; "I'm gonna... write a song about it."
"You won't be here tomorrow, will ya?"
Yeah. "You're going on holiday tomorrow, aren't you?"
"I just need something to get me started"
"What do you mean, get you started?"; "Oh, you know, in the morning."
So don't come on 'ere and tell us what we can--
--and cannot say and we can't say Kunz.
We can't say classical composers' names. Or philosophers, like Kant.
So don't tell us that, Karl.
Just play a record, what you got, Steve?
Yeah, I just think it's time that we listen to some Ride, Rick. We haven't listened to them, I don't know about you and I, but I haven't listened to some, to any for about six or seven weeks.
Just thought it would be good to have them on the air again.
And it's a tragedy that they split up. This is, uh, the classic Chelsea Girl. Play it, uh...
But they influenced lots of bands at that time.
The whole Brit-pop thing, and the... Wall of Sound and...
They weren't--were they shoegazers, do you think? They were, weren't they?
Well, that's what they're thought of, 'cause there's a lot of nooooodley guitar--
--but, uh, good melodies as well, Rick, and that's always important.
Don't know about, uh, you, Karl, but it is important to us.
We've just had, uh, a couple of people, Sarah and Claire call up and wish us luck for the BAFTA's... but, for some reason... they want one of us to do an impression of Leslie Phillips.
But, I want... I want Karl to do it, though.
You look like a ventriloquist dummy.
Do, uh, "My name is Bond, James Bond," as though it were Sean Connery.
"My name is Bond, James Bond." Do that, go on.
No, do it as though you were in--you were doing an impression.
I'm... what, so I'm trying to be Scottish?
Perhaps more specific than that, Sean Connery.
He's not bad, but this... this is the best fun.
He's like having your very own Fisher Price toy for two hours a week.
It's great. Um, do, um, uh... "Roger Moore..." Do that.
Ricky and Steve burst into laughter
(Manc accent)"Phyllis Pearce, Percy Sugden... licensed to kill."
So anyway, anyway, she just said--
No, this is a great game.
No no no no no, that's enough of it.
Yeah, we'll come back to this another time, Rick.
Yeah, anything, anything you want Karl to do--
Karl's homework today was to come up with those, you know those, um... lateral thinking things.

They're ridiculous, aren't they? Liketheyum, "A man went into a field and died." And you're meant to ask questions like, "Oh, was it abendiduh...?" and it turns out his parachute didn't open. So it's basically, it's not logic, it's "What am I thinking?"
Yeah... Well there's that one where there's a man in, this is the worst I've ever heard--
A man is found dead lying in a phone box...
He's bled to death and... there's glass everywhere.
Right? And the phone's hanging off--
Right. Do you know the answer is, Karl?
He was on the phone, someone asked him how big his fish was, he did that gesture like fishermen always do to sort of say that it was much bigger than it actually was.
His arms went through the glass and he slashed his wrists and he died.
Why would you do that with someone on the phone? When they can't see how big he's actually saying.
Well that's one of the many problems with that--
Yeah. Not the point we were making, but again, good. I mean, you're there. That is good thinking.
But, uh, so what, you had to come up with some of these? I didn't know this was his challenge.
Did you come up with one?
I came up with three. And they're all belters.
Are we gonna, oh, it's a... If it's as good... as... your... quote about happiness that we had to guess about which was yours and which was the real ones, like Faking It, I cannot wait.
I mean I literally can't wait, shall we do it now?
Well I'm tempted to save it, 'cause I just want to mention to people, um, that uh, they should be very excited because it's going to be Karl's special night tomorrow. You excited Karl?
Oh yeah, oh this is, yeah, um, eou, um, me and Steve 'cause we were nominated, we get a guest.

Um, um... and it, it doesn't say guest it actually says um, you know, uh, partner. So I'm taking, um, my partner and, uh, Steve's taking Karl. But what Karl doesn't realize is... you will have to pretend you're his partner otherwise you wouldn't be able to get in--
Yeah. We'll have to hold hands when we go down the red carpet.
He says, "Is this your... is this really your partner?" It's not just a guest. They have to--
That's how it is, and either we go in like that or we can't get in.
You have to, you just have to be with him when you go up there. I mean, you don't have to... does he have to hold--?
We should hold hands. But, what I think we should do is, just to make sure there is nothing at all that, like, is gonna go wrong, we should just do a little kiss.
Just in front of the cameras.
Or, or, or be seen sort of like... cheek to cheek. Just to show them that--
--you know, you're not, he's not just getting in--
That he's not just getting his mates in for a free meal and you are actually partners.
No... I'm not up for that.
Because we know we're not actually gay.
But you'd come out of it looking quite good 'cause you got a good lookin' fella'.
But I'm meant to, like, you know... I mean a... I'm not gay. But if I was... I don't think I'd go for you or summat.
Oh, he's done you Steve! He's turned on you again!
We were trying to get him--

Wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute... I have got the cream of London's totty phoning me up, trying to get an invite to the BAFTA's.
Right? We have very graciously asked you if you would like to come along.
Well that worries me even more... that you've got women calling you up.
Karl, I can't choose between them. If I let one of them down, I'm gonna, they're going to destroy them.
They--they'll be ruined, their lives will be ruined. It's better for me to take you and not, you know, ruin the lives of any of those poor women.
When--when-when he told them he was taking you it was like a scene from Graceland, there was just like--
He just had to say, "Look, just chill out, bitches." Didn't ya?
I did. I just said, "You know, you're all ma hoes"--
You know he gets, he could get you discount frocks?
Now I had a letter from the people, that there's an organization--
Now, listen Karl. There's an organization that sponsors the BAFTA awards--
--in terms of clothes and fashion; they've sent me a letter, they said, "Your partner", they've not specified the sex. They've said, "Your partner... can come along"--
--"and choose an outfit." Now I expect, by the look of it, it is a women's outfitters. I'm thinking we could get you a lovely trouser suit.
Why don't you have a trouser suit?
It may look feminine, right, but I think people will be fooled and they'll think it's a man suit.
It'll just be, it'll just be a little roomy in the hip--
And probably narrow in the shoulders, but you're a bit skinny; why don't you just take it, 'cause it's a lot of an insult.
And maybe just some pearls as well. It'll be lovely.
Well, I haven't got anything sorted to wear yet--
See, you're slagging me off, you're likely to end up to be going in a track suit.
I'm going out, I'm going out today. I've never bought a suit since I was, like, eleven, right?
I went to me brother's wedding, that's the last time I wore a suit.
Really? And you can't get anywhere near it now.
Can't get, can't get into that--
Em... that was a good day.
What was it? What sort of suit was it?
It was, uh, like a-da-da sort of a gray-silver one.
Well try and get something similar.
A gray-silver one... Just think of that with your little round head, what did you--what did that look like?
Like he'd landed from the moon--
I didn't, I didn't really need to wear a suit, either, 'cause I didn't--I hardly went into the church, I was in the car park, right? And it was when me brother was in the army.
And he a Ford Capri with one of them horns that go, "Doo da doo doo, doo da doo da doo doo doo"--
Why didn't he, why didn't he come in his tank?
I just sat in that, doing that all day and the vicar was getting well annoyed with me.
What, when the service was on?
It was driving everyone up the wall.

What do you, were you just allowed to do what you wanted when you were growing up? Like Nelson Muntz from The Simpsons? Did you just, were you just allowed--didn't matter--was there any discipline? You didn't have teachers, you didn't... did no one just... why didn't someone come out and--
I did, I got a couple of good hidings off me dad a couple of times.
Just... being mopey most of the time. If I had a strop on, he'd hate that.
He'd go, "Go out and burn something down or nick something but don't... don't wander round with your head down." Didn't he smack you for not liking a castle once?
No, no, what's that? What's that?

for the day. And I was bored, it was at that age where I just wanted to go in an arcade. And me dad was saying, "Come and see the castle, you know, there's history here." And I still don't like castles. It's just one of them things, again, it's just too far back to sort of, even... think about people living in 'em.
Do you know what I mean? So I was just like, "Look, it's a wreck, you know. Knock it down, flatten the thing."
And I was being really mopey.

And it's weird, 'cause now, like me mam and dad have retired and gone to Wales and now and again he takes me there and everytime we get to the point where he gave me a clout, he goes, "Are you getting flashbacks, son?"
Yeah. Well, a sobering lesson for you.
You're not on the British Heiratige Commitee anymore, are ya?
"This is the national trust land..."; "Tarmac it."
"It'll be the biggest... car park in Britain... for Christ's sake."
